posts.name: Alfa
posts.cooked: Hello, We are trying to make a CIM motor hold it‚Äôs position and withstand the weight of our arm but we don‚Äôt have an encoder. Is it possible without an encoder ? Thanks,

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Setting your motor controller on ‚Äúbrake mode‚Äù will help, but likely not be enough to keep an arm in position.

There are at least two options for open loop (that is, no encoder or other sensor required) solutions to this assuming that brake mode doesn‚Äôt work:

Use a gearbox that can‚Äôt be or at least resists backdriving.  Many worm gear boxes and some linear motion gearboxes are inefficient enough that they cannot be backdriven.  Big downside - if this arm is outside of your frame perimeter, it will likely be easily damaged when it runs into a wall or another robot.

Counter weight or counter springs.  Put some weight or springs so that the arm is naturally balanced (or at least close), then the CIM in brake mode will be enough.  The funky monkeys (FRC 846) did a video on tuning a counter spring a couple of years ago: Counterbalancing a Robot's Arm Using Springs WVROX 2020 - YouTube

link_counts.title: Counterbalancing a Robot's Arm Using Springs WVROX 2020 - YouTube

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
I believe the other option requires a bit of math around the system you are trying to hold in place. There are great community resources for calculators for mechanical design

Calculators | Onshape4FRC

You can calculate roughly the amount of voltage/current required to hold your mechanical system in place. Granted it‚Äôs not going to be robust against the forces of your robot moving or hitting something, but if your gear ratio is high enough it can help make this easier. Current draw of a system in of itself is a type of feedback which isn‚Äôt exactly like a sensor, but it can help. I can‚Äôt remember exactly there may have been a talk done by Austin Shuh of 971 about modeling system components for software where he discusses this topic further.

posts.name: Alfa
posts.cooked: So should we buy cimcoders? would that help?

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
An encoder or other feedback sensor is the best method for holding a position.  However, it requires several key components that are beyond some teams.  In particular:

You must have a programming crew up to the task.  If you‚Äôre using a CAN-based motor controller and can tie the sensor directly to the controller, the coding is simpler than if you bring the sensor info back to the RIO, which you‚Äôll need to do for a PWM-based controller.

You must have enough mechanical and wiring prowess to mount the sensor so that there is a minimum of backlash (that is, slop and wiggle between the physical location of what you‚Äôre controlling and the value the sensor reports),

Keep the sensor from being damaged in operation, including FRC gameplay, AND

have robust enough electrical connections to survive the same gameplay.

Additionally, even the encoder/sensor solution is MUCH more effective if you do a counter balance solution as well.  Given how far into the season we are already, and that your team presumably does not have much experience with sensors, I would start with implementing a counter-spring.   And if you do any off-season work, figure out the sensor feedback this summer or next autumn so you know how to do it next year.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve seen bicycle brake rotors used to help; some servos can actuate these (in place of the lever on one of the handgrips).  But, you have to build this thing, and you might still want an encoder ‚Äì this is the usual way to tell where am arm is oriented, to facilitate position control, etc.

Also, motors don‚Äôt like to operate at stall.  If you can balance things at a low enough power level (current), a CIM may be OK ‚Äì they are pretty good at dissipating power / handling heat.

Some number of switches that detect preset positions might be another option.  But an encoder is often easier/better‚Ä¶

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked:
In the olden days we did this, but you‚Äôll want to balance the load with weights or a spring‚Ä¶keeping power on the motor makes them hot quickly.

there are fins that are sold for CIM motors, but most of the heat is in the rotor, not the frame, so they didn‚Äôt work that well.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.custom_user_title: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: It depends. If it is a relatively static load and lots of reduction. You measure how much command it takes to hold the load. Use that number to hold the load. This is not perfect, if you have a disturbance it will move. This is called open loop control.
